awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Costumer Discovery for Demand-responsive Transverse Rumble Strips
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a safety device to reduce traffic crashes, injuries, and fatalities. Existing alternative technologies alone are unable to address the existing demand. In the U.S, nearly 6,000 pedestrian fatalities and 70,000 pedestrian injuries occur each year. From 2016 to 2017 there was a 27% increase in pedestrian fatalities. Additionally, 130,000 schools across the United States need enhanced techniques to increase driver alertness. In 2017, over 2,000 crashes resulting in 289 deaths occurred at rail crossings. A strong global demand exists for the proposed traffic safety device because there are not alternatives with similar effectiveness. Because the proposed device will be active only when required, it has a much broader range of applications compared to alternative technologies. For example, the proposed devise provides redundancy in the case of autonomous vehicles to minimize the likelihood of crashes due to failures and/or malfunction in the detection or navigation systems. That is, the proposed device provides an alternative communication channel to alert the autonomous vehicle to slow down or stop. The concept behind the proposed device to enhance safety can be extended to other environments such as construction sites. 

This I-Corps project is about customer discovery for a Demand-Responsive Transverse Rumble Strip (DRTRS) mechanism, which becomes active (lowers an array of strips) only when necessary to alert drivers and vehicles through noise and vibration of downstream risks. Permanent transverse rumble strips are mainly used on approaches to intersections, toll plazas, horizontal curves, and work zones to slow down traffic. Traditional transverse rumble strips have been shown to be effective. However, drivers become familiar with their location over time and their effectiveness tends to diminish. Unnecessary noise, vehicle deterioration, and pavement wear out are additional concerns associated with traditional transverse rumble strips. The intellectual merits of our research are: (i) an effective and deployable DRTRS mechanism that addresses the above issues and (ii) evaluation of its effectiveness and required maintenance. The proposed intellectual merits required addressing simultaneously significant challenges including operability and reliability under extreme environmental and heterogeneous traffic conditions, small depth to minimize affecting the integrity of the existing pavement, easy and rapid maintenance and replacement, minimal maintenance schedules, and durability under snow plow operations. In addition, this project is helping us improve our understanding of using acoustic and haptic senses to prevent accidents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We completed the I-Corps training and performed customer discovery following the guidance provided by the instructors. We learned about the Business Model Canvas framework and associated process to perform our customer discovery. The training included literature review and site workshops. We met with multiple people who successfully completed the training and learned about their experience. All of them were able to commercialize their technology and some of them have been useful with multiple products. We learned how to communicate with potential customers and what questions to ask. We also learned how to estimate important relevant statistics such as potential market size. Weekly phone, video and in person interviews were used to get insights from potential customers and stakeholders to learn about their problems and limitations of existing alternative solutions. We travelled across the United States to collect information from different groups of potential customers. We talked to government agencies, consultants, vendors of alternative solutions, and traffic safety advocates. We concluded that our proposed solution has significant potential for commercialization and adoption but requires fundamental improvements to handle maintenance requirements and constraints for highway infrastructure. The knowledge and experience that we got through the I-Corps program is helping with current field testing of our proposed solution. In addition, we are currently partnering with local businesses and government organizations to improve the technology and meet the require maintenance goals.

Outcomes relevant to Intellectual Merit:

We learned that our technology has potential for commercialization but improvements are required to meet maintenance constraints. We are currently working on new designs to meet the requirements.

Outcomes relevant to Broader Impacts:

The proposed technology delivers benefits by providing an alternative passive communication channel which could be used both in conventional and for driverless vehicles.
